name: Canada Goose
description: A robust goose with a black head and neck, gray-beige body, white underbelly, and black tail. Its legs are gray. A distinctive feature is the broad white throat strap.
spread_note: From northern Mexico to Alaska, occasionally straying to northern Europe; introduced to New Zealand and the British Isles.
food_note: Aquatic and terrestrial plants, seeds, also grains
image_alt: Canada goose, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Body length 43–93 cm; tail length 12–17 cm; wingspan 122–183 cm; weight 2–6.5 kg
reproduction: Females lay 5–7 eggs and incubate them for 28–30 days.
attractions: They stay near still or slow-moving waters, using their strong beaks to nip off parts of aquatic and terrestrial plants. Canada geese live in pairs formed during wintering or migration, often lasting several years or a lifetime. They nest on the ground in undergrowth near water. Breeding sites are farther north in their range, and they migrate to southern areas for winter.
breeding: It comprises several subspecies, of which the Labrador subspecies (B. c. canadensis) can be seen at Prague Zoo, sharing an enclosure with bison.
